<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two parallel cylindrical conductors each have a small cross-sectional area \(A\). A thin metal bar connects the two conductors, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 114, 819, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 332, 591, 351]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
The metal bar has a square cross-section with sides of length \(y\). For each conductor, the distance between its end C and the centre of the metal bar is \(L\). The distance between the centres of the conductors is \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 426, 890, 445]]<|/det|>
The ends C are connected to a power supply and the current \(I\) in the conductors is measured.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 457, 562, 476]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(I\) is related to \(L\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 481, 562, 514]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{E}{I} = \frac{2PL}{A} +\frac{Qx}{y^2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 518, 865, 537]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the power supply, and \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 550, 690, 568]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(I\) and \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 581, 625, 600]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 703, 630]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 384, 661]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 395, 692]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 704, 410, 721]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 734, 348, 751]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 764, 351, 781]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 793, 447, 810]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 803, 91]]<|/det|>
The brightness of some stars varies regularly. These stars are called variable stars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 688, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the variation of luminosity with time for a variable star.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 129, 740, 298]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 314, 534, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 680, 364]]<|/det|>
A student determines the period \(T\) and mean luminosity \(L\) of the star.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 377, 606, 395]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the process for different variable stars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 571, 427]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(L\) and \(T\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 439, 541, 457]]<|/det|>
\[L = S K T^{a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 648, 488]]<|/det|>
where \(S\) is the luminosity of the Sun, and \(a\) and \(K\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 501, 146, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 501, 685, 520]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\lg L\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\lg T\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 611, 551]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 686, 917, 705]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 718, 917, 736]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 733, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 487, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(T\) and \(L\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 128, 845, 400]]<|/det|>
\(T/\)days\(L/10^{30}W\)lg (T/days)lg (L/10^{30}W)
222.9 ± 0.2
324.9 ± 0.2
426.9 ± 0.2
549.8 ± 0.2
7816 ± 2
9721 ± 2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 761, 433]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of lg ( \(T/\) days) and lg ( \(L/10^{30}W)\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 579, 447]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in lg ( \(L/10^{30}W)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 429, 920, 448]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 144, 479]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 460, 176, 479]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 460, 599, 479]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of lg ( \(L/10^{30}W)\) against lg ( \(T/\) days). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 476, 489, 494]]<|/det|> Include error bars for lg ( \(L/10^{30}W)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 476, 920, 494]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 507, 180, 526]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 507, 920, 540]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 554, 180, 573]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 554, 920, 587]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 772, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
gradient = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 256, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 148, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 288, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(a\) and \(K\). Include the absolute uncertainties in your values. You need not be concerned with units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 371, 351]]<|/det|>
Data: \(S = 3.85 \times 10^{26} \text{W}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 551, 917, 570]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 583, 920, 601]]<|/det|>
<form>K = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 598, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 144, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 630, 485, 647]]<|/det|>
A variable star has a period of 5.0 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 475, 677]]<|/det|>
Determine the luminosity \(L\) of this star.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 828, 920, 847]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... W [1]
